Yes, efforts are being made in Australia to address the historic injustices suffered by Indigenous peoples and to reconcile the past.

One example is the National Apology delivered by former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd in 2008, which acknowledged the harm that was caused to Indigenous peoples through forced removals, assimilation policies, and other forms of discrimination. The apology was an important step towards acknowledging the wrongs of the past and beginning a process of healing and reconciliation.

Another example is the ongoing process of land rights and native title in Australia. Through granting native title to Indigenous peoples, traditional lands and territories are being returned to their rightful owners, providing greater autonomy and self-determination for Indigenous communities.

In addition, there are a range of policies and programs that are being implemented to support Indigenous peoples' cultural practices, language revitalization, and economic development. The Australian government, for instance, has invested significant resources into Closing the Gap, a program aimed at addressing the disparities in health, education, and economic outcomes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians.

While there is more work to be done, these efforts are important steps towards building a more equitable and just society for Indigenous peoples in Australia.
